articles.headline: U.S. and Allies Move to Further Isolate Russia From Global Economy
articles.snippet: The Biden administration said it would join Europe and other allies in stripping Russia of permanent normal trade relations, another step to inflict economic damage on the country over its invasion of Ukraine.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration said it would join Europe and other allies in stripping Russia of permanent normal trade relations, another step to inflict economic damage on the country over its invasion of Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden and other Western leaders moved on Friday to further isolate Russia from the global trading system, saying they would strip the country of normal trade relations and take other steps to sever its links to the world economy in response to President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion of Ukraine.

articles.headline: Bitcoin Was Made for This Moment. So Why Isn’t It Booming?
articles.snippet: Long hailed by its advocates as a safe hedge during uncertain times, Bitcoin’s value has fallen steadily in recent weeks.
articles.abstract: Long hailed by its advocates as a safe hedge during uncertain times, Bitcoin’s value has fallen steadily in recent weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Bitcoin buffs who were questioned by skeptics about the value of the cryptocurrency would respond by saying: just wait.

articles.headline: Roman Abramovich’s Fortune Bought Him Good Will, and Made Him a Target
articles.snippet: The oligarch’s billions and his Kremlin connections secured him favors and elite status in the West. Now they’ve landed him on a sanctions list.
articles.abstract: The oligarch’s billions and his Kremlin connections secured him favors and elite status in the West. Now they’ve landed him on a sanctions list.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Russian troops massed near the border with Ukraine last month, the American ambassador to Israel received an appeal on behalf of Roman Abramovich, the most visible of the billionaires linked to President Vladimir V. Putin.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick, Isabel Kershner, Rory Smith and Tariq Panja

articles.headline: Facebook’s Parent Company Will Make Employees Do Their Own Laundry
articles.snippet: The company told workers on Friday that it will reduce or eliminate some of its famous perks as it prepares for a return to the office.
articles.abstract: The company told workers on Friday that it will reduce or eliminate some of its famous perks as it prepares for a return to the office.
articles.lead_paragraph: The salad days of Facebook’s lavish employee perks may be coming to an end.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac, Ryan Mac and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: How a Line of Russian Tanks Became an Inviting Target for Ukrainians
articles.snippet: A skirmish in an eastern suburb of Kyiv illustrated how close Russian forces have come as they continued to tighten a noose on the city, but also revealed their strategic vulnerabilities.
articles.abstract: A skirmish in an eastern suburb of Kyiv illustrated how close Russian forces have come as they continued to tighten a noose on the city, but also revealed their strategic vulnerabilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: BROVARY, Ukraine — The column of Russian tanks rumbled along a main highway to the east of Kyiv, between two rows of houses in a small town — a vulnerable target.

articles.headline: Slowed on the Battlefield, Russia Widens Bombardment of Ukrainian Cities
articles.snippet: But military experts, citing previous Russian campaigns, say that strategy is unlikely to succeed without bloody urban fighting.
articles.abstract: But military experts, citing previous Russian campaigns, say that strategy is unlikely to succeed without bloody urban fighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Russian military struck Ukrainian cities far from the main battle lines on Friday, pressing its strategy of bombing Ukraine into submission as the country plunged deeper into misery and privation more than two weeks into the war.
articles.byline: By Michael Levenson, Eric Schmitt and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: Texas Supreme Court Shuts Down Final Challenge to Abortion Law
articles.snippet: The ruling says state officials have no authority to enforce the law, which empowers private citizens: “We cannot rewrite the statute.”
articles.abstract: The ruling says state officials have no authority to enforce the law, which empowers private citizens: “We cannot rewrite the statute.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The Texas Supreme Court on Friday effectively shut down a federal challenge to the state’s novel and controversial ban on abortion after about six weeks of pregnancy, closing off what abortion rights advocates said was their last, narrow path to blocking the new law.
articles.byline: By Kate Zernike and Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Shaming Apple and Texting Musk, a Ukraine Minister Uses Novel War Tactics
articles.snippet: Mykhailo Fedorov, Ukraine’s youngest minister, has turned technology, cryptocurrency and social media into modern weapons of war.
articles.abstract: Mykhailo Fedorov, Ukraine’s youngest minister, has turned technology, cryptocurrency and social media into modern weapons of war.
articles.lead_paragraph: After war began last month, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine turned to Mykhailo Fedorov, a vice prime minister, for a key role.

articles.headline: House Democrats Push Biden to Build a Better Midterm Message
articles.snippet: House Democrats have been pressing the president to come up with a bumper-sticker-worthy slogan. The White House says it’s sharpening its message.
articles.abstract: House Democrats have been pressing the president to come up with a bumper-sticker-worthy slogan. The White House says it’s sharpening its message.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After offering her customary lavish praise of President Biden, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi got to the business at hand at a White House meeting last month on the midterm elections.

articles.headline: What It Was Like to Work for Russian State Television
articles.snippet: Until RT America ended abruptly, life as a journalist there was “actually so normal.”
articles.abstract: Until RT America ended abruptly, life as a journalist there was “actually so normal.”
articles.lead_paragraph: For eight years, Lee Camp hosted a weekly show on RT America that aimed to satirize American politics, finding punchlines in subjects like sanctions against Afghanistan and student debt forgiveness. That ended unceremoniously on March 3, a week after Russian airstrikes began in Ukraine, when the Russian-state-funded network suddenly shut down.

articles.headline: Pandemic Fears Give Way to a Rush for Bomb Shelters
articles.snippet: Since Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, European anxiety has shifted from Covid to nuclear annihilation. Bunkers, survival guides and iodine pills are flying off the shelves.
articles.abstract: Since Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, European anxiety has shifted from Covid to nuclear annihilation. Bunkers, survival guides and iodine pills are flying off the shelves.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGNOLO SAN VITO, Italy — Across a footbridge from a busy shopping outlet surrounded by verdant fields in northern Italy, workers in a nondescript warehouse are preparing for a nuclear attack, its radioactive fallout and the end of the world as we know it.

articles.headline: Ukraine War Ushers In ‘New Era’ for U.S. Abroad
articles.snippet: President Biden is rethinking relationships with allies as well as rivals — including China, Iran and Venezuela — to counter President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
articles.abstract: President Biden is rethinking relationships with allies as well as rivals — including China, Iran and Venezuela — to counter President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The war in Ukraine has prompted the biggest rethinking of American foreign policy since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, infusing the United States with a new sense of mission and changing its strategic calculus with allies and adversaries alike.
articles.byline: By Michael Crowley and Edward Wong

articles.headline: U.S. to Send Arms to Ukraine, as Russia Intensifies Campaign of Destruction
articles.snippet: A defiant mayor of a captured city was kidnapped by Russian troops, Ukrainian authorities say, an act that prompted hundreds to protest.
articles.abstract: A defiant mayor of a captured city was kidnapped by Russian troops, Ukrainian authorities say, an act that prompted hundreds to protest.
articles.lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — Russian forces stepped up their campaign of bombardments aimed at devastating Ukraine’s cities and towns on Saturday, as the White House announced it was sending an additional $200 million in arms and equipment to help Ukraine, defying Moscow.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora, Michael Schwirtz and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: In a Kyiv Basement, 19 Surrogate Babies Are Trapped by War but Kept Alive by Nannies
articles.snippet: Some surrogate mothers are trapped by the fighting as their due dates near. And newborns face uncertain fates, with many biological parents now unable to travel to Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Some surrogate mothers are trapped by the fighting as their due dates near. And newborns face uncertain fates, with many biological parents now unable to travel to Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Down a dusty stairwell, hidden from the shelling that has become the grim background noise of Ukraine’s capital, Ludmila Yashenko fusses with the babies. There are 19 of them, sleeping or cooing in neatly arranged cribs, fed regularly from tubs of baby formula.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Lynsey Addario

articles.headline: As a Crisis Hotline Grows, So Do Fears It Won’t Be Ready
articles.snippet: Envisioned as the 911 for mental health, the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline will soon be 988, with more services for more callers. But it’s already straining to meet demand.
articles.abstract: Envisioned as the 911 for mental health, the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline will soon be 988, with more services for more callers. But it’s already straining to meet demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: First Amendment Scholars Want to See the Media Lose These Cases
articles.snippet: Some legal experts say it is time to draw a sharp line between protected speech and harmful disinformation.
articles.abstract: Some legal experts say it is time to draw a sharp line between protected speech and harmful disinformation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The lawyers and First Amendment scholars who have made it their life’s work to defend the well-established but newly threatened constitutional protections for journalists don’t usually root for the media to lose in court.

articles.headline: The Key to a $4 Billion Fraud Case: A Banker Who Says He ‘Lied a Lot’
articles.snippet: Only one person is likely to ever face trial in the United States over the looted billions from a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund. The case hangs on his former boss at Goldman Sachs.
articles.abstract: Only one person is likely to ever face trial in the United States over the looted billions from a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund. The case hangs on his former boss at Goldman Sachs.
articles.lead_paragraph: It seemed a facetious question, one intended to provoke the star witness: “Do you think you are good at lying?”

articles.headline: ‘Things Will Only Get Worse.’ Putin’s War Sends Russians Into Exile.
articles.snippet: Thousands of Russians saw their comfortable, middle-class lives fade overnight with the invasion ordered by President Vladimir V. Putin.
articles.abstract: Thousands of Russians saw their comfortable, middle-class lives fade overnight with the invasion ordered by President Vladimir V. Putin.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — They lined up at A.T.M.s, desperate for cash after Visa and Mastercard suspended operations in Russia, swapping intelligence on where they could still get dollars. At Istanbul cafes, they sat quietly studying Telegram chats or Google Maps on their phones. They organized support groups to help other Russian exiles find housing.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Patrick Kingsley

articles.headline: Frustrated With Utilities, Some Californians Are Leaving the Grid
articles.snippet: Citing more blackouts, wildfires and higher electricity rates, a growing number of homeowners are choosing to build homes that run entirely on solar panels and batteries.
articles.abstract: Citing more blackouts, wildfires and higher electricity rates, a growing number of homeowners are choosing to build homes that run entirely on solar panels and batteries.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEVADA CITY, Calif. — In the Gold Rush, Northern California attracted prospectors looking for financial independence. Now, this area is at the vanguard of a new movement — people seeking to use only the energy they produce themselves.

articles.headline: Booms, Smoke and Fire Signal Horror of Russian Attack on Base
articles.snippet: Residents of a town near Poland’s border awoke to frightful sounds and an awareness they were no longer safe.
articles.abstract: Residents of a town near Poland’s border awoke to frightful sounds and an awareness they were no longer safe.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOVOYAVORIVSK, Ukraine — Hours after Russian missiles decimated a military base near the Polish border on Sunday, soldiers in camouflage were still being wheeled out of an overwhelmed nearby hospital on stretchers, many in so much pain they could only turn their heads to reveal eyes stricken with fear.
articles.byline: By Valerie Hopkins and Yousur Al-Hlou

articles.headline: How Does It End? A Way Out of the Ukraine War Proves Elusive.
articles.snippet: Attempts at diplomacy have hit a stone wall as President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia refuses to engage in any serious negotiation, but his endgame is unclear.
articles.abstract: Attempts at diplomacy have hit a stone wall as President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia refuses to engage in any serious negotiation, but his endgame is unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States accurately predicted the start of the war in Ukraine, sounding the alarm that an invasion was imminent despite Moscow’s denials and Europe’s skepticism. Predicting how it might end is proving far more difficult.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Russian Airstrike at NATO’s Doorstep Raises Fears of Expanded War
articles.snippet: Russian missiles hit a military base being used to train foreign volunteers who want to help Ukraine repel the invasion, killing a reported 35 people just 11 miles from the Polish border.
articles.abstract: Russian missiles hit a military base being used to train foreign volunteers who want to help Ukraine repel the invasion, killing a reported 35 people just 11 miles from the Polish border.
articles.lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — Russia launched a barrage of airstrikes on Sunday against a military base in western Ukraine where American troops had trained Ukrainian forces just weeks earlier, bringing the war 11 miles from the border with Poland, where NATO forces are stationed on high alert.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora, Jack Nicas and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: How High Oil Prices Threaten a California Plastic Container Business
articles.snippet: Rising energy costs are lifting the prices of key materials and intensifying inflation, compounding supply chain disruptions caused by the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Rising energy costs are lifting the prices of key materials and intensifying inflation, compounding supply chain disruptions caused by the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Long before President Vladimir V. Putin unleashed his war on Ukraine, Mosharraf Khalid was already contending with an expensive, bewildering and unrelenting assortment of problems afflicting the global supply chain.

articles.headline: A Fatal Crossing on the Northern Border
articles.snippet: A family from India froze to death just yards away from crossing into the United States from Canada. Desperate migrants are trying their luck on the northern border.
articles.abstract: A family from India froze to death just yards away from crossing into the United States from Canada. Desperate migrants are trying their luck on the northern border.
articles.lead_paragraph: PEMBINA, N.D. — The air temperature was pushing 20 below zero and howling winds were whipping up blinding snow one morning in January when U.S. Border Patrol agents in North Dakota spotted five human forms moving through the barren borderland where America and Canada meet.

articles.headline: China Sees at Least One Winner Emerging From Ukraine War: China
articles.snippet: The country’s leaders think it can shield itself from economic and diplomatic fallout and eventually be seen as a pillar of stability.
articles.abstract: The country’s leaders think it can shield itself from economic and diplomatic fallout and eventually be seen as a pillar of stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: The war in Ukraine is far from over, but a consensus is forming in Chinese policy circles that one country stands to emerge victorious from the turmoil: China.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: Apple iPhone SE Review: A Phone for the Anti-Consumer
articles.snippet: Why spend more if you don’t have to? The new $430 iPhone meets all the criteria of what most of us need in a smartphone.
articles.abstract: Why spend more if you don’t have to? The new $430 iPhone meets all the criteria of what most of us need in a smartphone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple has a new, cheaper iPhone arriving in stores on Friday that encapsulates the bare minimum of what we need in a smartphone. The latest iPhone SE has a bright screen, a zippy processor, a quality camera and robust battery life. It makes phone calls, too.

articles.headline: Powell Admires Paul Volcker. He May Have to Act Like Him.
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve is facing the fastest inflation most Americans have ever seen. Its chair says policymakers will do what it takes to tame prices.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve is facing the fastest inflation most Americans have ever seen. Its chair says policymakers will do what it takes to tame prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: To Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, Paul Volcker is more than a predecessor. He is one of his professional heroes.
